creditline: Gift of Professor Alfred Moir in memory of Louis Nippert Zelle
description: Seated man playing a lyre, with various animals and birds seated and perched on branches around him; inscriptions at top and bottom; mounted to ivory sheet with grey and gold borders
inscription:
Inscribed bottom center in pen and brown ink: \"Orphaeus\"; bottom left in pen and brown ink; a heptagon with the sides numbered, within a square with the words \"septangano\" (?) written over it; across the top in pen and in the same brown ink a fragmentary  paragraph: 

Caliope tuono il numero Sette... ario, hebbe p della lyra la quale Hesedito (?) da lyno, et -- fiere et gli arbori et i sassi et gli ucelli --\"  [R.J. Campbell, Old Master Drawings from the Collection of Alfred Moir, 2000, no. 27]

According to Jean-Luc Baroni the inscription reads: Calliope trovo il numero settenario, hebbe p... della lyra la quale heredito da Lyni, et fiere er gli arbori et i sassi et gli ucelli\" [Exh. cat. Douwes Fine Art, June 30 - July 12, 1980]
markings: \"C\" (Lugt 474, formerly thought to be the mark of P. Crozat)
medium: Pen and brown ink on white laid paper
provenance:
Unidentified collection (L 474, formerly thought to be the mark of P. Crozat);
Private Collection, New Zealand (Sale, Christie's, London, July 4, 1972, lot 67 [group lot], to Baskett and Day, 420 gns); [Baskett and Day, London, since 1972]; [Jean-Luc Baroni, London, in 1980, sold to Moir]; Prof. Alfred Moir, Santa Barbara, CA, 1980-2003, gave to MIA
title: Orpheus Charming the Beasts
